awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Structural and Topological Controls on Viscoelasticity and Relaxation Processes in Chalcogenide Glass-Forming Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Chalcogenide (non-oxide alloys or compounds containing sulfur, selenium or tellurium)   glasses are an important class of materials with wide-ranging applications in the areas of photonics, telecommunication, memory storage, photovoltaics and environmental remote sensing. A fundamental understanding of the dynamical processes associated with the temperature- and composition- dependent flow behavior of the parent   melts or liquids from which these glasses are derived, is crucial in all stages of their industrial production. This project aims to provide unique knowledge regarding the connection between the "microscopic (atomistic)" and the "macroscopic" aspects of the dynamical behavior of chalcogenide liquids   for the very first time, using a combination of cutting-edge characterization techniques. This knowledge is key to the optimization of the chemistry and processing parameters of these materials for improved and novel functionality, thereby enabling their application in modern transformative technologies with strong societal impact. Scientifically, this work impacts materials science, physical chemistry, and solid-state physics. The interdisciplinary nature of this work transfers knowledge between fields and provides students with unique opportunities for intellectual growth. Graduates typically find employment in both academia and in glass and semiconductor industry. The impact of this project in terms of education and outreach is in three major areas: (1) participation by students in research, (2) active and tight-knit collaboration with industry (Corning, Inc.) where students are mentored and gain understanding of industry priorities, and (3) dissemination of knowledge about glass science and technology to the broader scientific community. The research findings are embedded into special topics courses that are offered to students in materials science, chemistry, and other related fields; and they contribute to campus programs for women and minority students and to the recruitment of promising students from underrepresented and economically-disadvantaged groups.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The dynamical processes in supercooled glass-forming liquids, associated with their viscous flow, structural relaxation and annealing near the glass transition, control all aspects of the processing and technological utility of the resulting glasses and glass-ceramics. However, surprisingly enough, little is known regarding the connection between the atomic structure, its connectivity and topology and the temperature dependence of the flow behavior of chalcogenide liquids. Historically, therefore, much of the approach for designing new chalcogenide glasses has been largely empirical and lacked the predictive power needed for their compositional optimization and processing methods. This GOALI project brings together investigators with complementary expertise and common interests from UC Davis (Sen, PI) and from Corning Incorporated (Aitken, co-PI), to investigate the effects of structural connectivity and topology on the temperature dependence of the viscoelastic behavior and relaxation processes in supercooled chalcogenide (sulfide and selenide) liquids, using a unique combination of state-of-the-art oscillatory parallel-plate rheometry, dynamical nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and differential scanning calorimetry measurements. Predictive atomistic models of structure-relaxation-viscous flow relationships, built on the basis of the results obtained in this project, may enable the optimization of the chemistry, synthesis, and processing parameters of these complex materials for a wide range of modern technological applications. The focus of this project, namely how and why, the various aspects of the atomic structure control the temperature dependent viscoelasticity, relaxational behavior and related phenomena in chalcogenide glass-forming liquids is in itself crosscutting materials research. The breadth, flexibility and interdisciplinary nature of this project prepare the students with powerful experimental skills and research experience in both academic and industrial settings that may open many future career opportunities. It also enriches the graduate education and training experience through numerous scientific interactions   between the collaborating scientists and participating students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Chalcogenide glasses are sulfides, selenides or tellurides, mainly of Ge, As, P and Si, with wide-ranging applications in the areas of photonics, telecommunication, memory storage, photovoltaics and environmental remote sensing.  A fundamental understanding of the dynamical processes associated with the viscous flow and relaxation behavior of the parent melts or liquids from which these glasses are derived, is crucial in all stages of their industrial production.  However, surprisingly enough, little was known regarding the connection between the atomic structure, its connectivity and topology and the temperature dependence of the flow behavior of chalcogenide glass-forming liquids. This GOALI project brought together investigators with complementary expertise and common interests from UC Davis (Sen, PI) and from CRDC, Corning Incorporated’s main R&D laboratory and world’s foremost innovator and commercial developer of cutting-edge glass technology, (Bruce Aitken, CRDC advisor) to address this gap in knowledge.  This knowledge is key to the optimization of the composition and processing parameters of these glasses for improved and novel functionality, thereby enabling their application in transformative technologies with strong societal impact.

Over the duration of this project groundbreaking accomplishments have been made in building atomic-scale mechanistic understanding of the flow behavior of chalcogenide glass-forming liquids that have provided key fundamental information to establish the much-needed direct connection between structure, topology and dynamics. The latter enabled critical experimental verification of the predictive models of viscoelasticity and relaxation phenomena that are at the heart of compositional optimization of these glasses for forming and annealing processes. The major scientific achievements of this project are as follows. (1) A fundamental understanding of the role of various structural moieties in chalcogenide liquids, ranging from molecules to short and long chains, in controlling their flow behavior is obtained.  (2) The shear thinning mechanism in network liquids is found to be fundamentally different from those in molecular, metallic or polymeric glass-formers.  (3) Unlike network liquids, the molecular chalcogenide liquids are found to display an extremely broad distribution of relaxation timescales, which may be linked to their steep temperature dependence of viscosity.

This project provided major opportunities for training and professional development of five PhD students (Weidi Zhu, Yiqing Xia, Bing Yuan, Jacob Lovi and Ido Chuang).   Industry Co-PI Bruce Aitken worked closely with the graduate students in providing mentoring and training. As part of this GOALI project, students were hosted at CRDC throughout the duration of the project, although the 2020 annual trip to CRDC had to be canceled due to the Covid-19 pandemic.  This industry-university collaboration provided a unique opportunity in broadening these participating students' horizons in terms of research experience both in academia and in industry.  Weidi completed his Ph.D. in 2020 and is currently a materials engineer in the R&D group of Apple Inc.; Yiqing completed his Ph.D. in 2021 and is currently a glass scientist in the R&D group of Heraeus Photovoltaics, while Bing completed her Ph.D. in 2022 and is currently pursuing post-doctoral work.  Jacob and Ido are scheduled to finish their PhD in 2026 and 2027, respectively.

The PI and his research group have been active in outreach efforts throughout the duration of this project.  The notable outreach efforts included (a) the training and mentoring of four Junior and Senior undergraduate students, including two women and two underrepresented minority students. As part of their mentoring, these students were given exposure to the key aspects of the research problems and techniques associated with the project and provided with cutting-edge research experience in the laboratory. This resulted in multiple publications jointly authored with one of the students; and (b) local outreach efforts at K-12 level, which included graduate students visiting the Winters Middle School in 2019 and giving a demonstration to the 7th graders on glass structure and stability.  Unfortunately, such activities got disrupted in 2020-21 and 2021-22 school years due to the Covid pandemic.  However, we brought back these outreach activities in the 2022-23 academic year as graduate student Jacob Lovi volunteered with the local chapter of the Boys and Girls Club of America where he developed a STEM activity module highlighting the interaction of glass with light, targeted for kids between the ages of 6 and 12.

Besides our collaboration with CRDC, this project fostered a very fruitful collaboration with scientists at the National High Magnetic Field Lab, who provided opportunities for our group to interact with world-renowned spectroscopists. During this grant period PI Sen co-organized multiple sessions at the American Ceramic Society Glass & Optical Materials Division (GOMD) meetings every year.  He also served as a member of the GOMD Executive Committee in 2019 and 2020.  Sen and the students presented 9 invited and 8 contributed talks at various national and international conferences and workshops. The research work supported by this grant resulted in the publication of a total of 35 papers in prominent peer-reviewed journals.
